docs.title: Welcome to KCD Kuala Lumpur
docs.text:
KCD Kuala Lumpur 2026 is a community-driven event that brings together cloud native enthusiasts, practitioners, and experts from across Malaysia, APAC region and all over the world. As part of the global Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF) initiative, KCD Kuala Lumpur serves as a platform to learn, collaborate and celebrate all things Kubernetes and cloud native.

We’re organizing the event to feature in-depth sessions, hands-on workshops, technical deep dives, and community activities designed to inspire both beginners and seasoned professionals. Whether you’re exploring your first Kubernetes deployment or managing large-scale production clusters, KCD Kuala Lumpur 2026 aims to create meaningful conversations and practical learning experiences that everyone can take home.

This event is proudly organized by local community leaders from Cloud Native Kuala Lumpur who are passionate about building a stronger cloud native ecosystem in Malaysia. Expect a vibrant mix of technical talks, real-world case studies, networking opportunities, panel discussions, and live demos — all shaped by the community, for the community.

Join us in Kuala Lumpur as we connect, share knowledge, and push the boundaries of what’s possible in the cloud native and open source world.

Let’s grow the ecosystem, elevate local talent and drive innovation together at KCD Kuala Lumpur 2026!

#TeamCloudNative #TeamOpenSource

docs.title: Get Your Tickets
docs.text: Coming soon

docs.title: Financial Support for Speakers
docs.text:
Note

The availability of financial support is tied to the event’s budget. We may need to limit the number of support or adjust the amount accordingly. And this is a reimbursement program which means that funds will not be provided upfront, but reimbursed after the event, based on the submitted invoice and receipts. In some cases, the financial support may not cover all costs and it is the responsibility of the speaker to cover any remaining expenses

Warning

In case we couldn't secure enough budget, unfortunately, we won't be able to provide any financial support for the speakers

We are excited to offer conditional financial support for speakers from either Sabah/Sarawak or overseas attending our event. This program is designed to help support and facilitate the participation of talented individuals from outside of Peninsular Malaysia. Please note that this financial support is on a need basis and contingent on our event's overall budget.

docs.title: Eligibility Criteria
docs.text:
• Overseas or Sabah/Sarawak Speakers Only: This financial support is available exclusively to speakers who reside outside of Peninsular Malaysia including Sabah, Sarawak and overseas and are traveling specifically for this event.
  • Need-Based: The financial support is provided based on need. Applicants must demonstrate why they need financial assistance to participate in the event
  • Event Budget: The total number of speakers who will be given the financial support and the amount available depends on the event's budget. We aim to provide support but may have limited resources based on event funding. Not all applicants will necessarily receive support

docs.title: Financial Support Details
docs.text:
• Maximum Amount: Each eligible speaker can receive a maximum of MYR 1000 (estimated around $250 and the final amount might be lesser due to currency conversion fees, banking fees, etc.) to help cover travel and/or accommodation expenses
  • Reimbursement Process: If you are approved for the support, you will need to submit an invoice for the eligible expenses after the event for reimbursement
  • Expenses Covered: The financial support can help with travel and/or accommodation, provided these expenses are deemed necessary and justified
  • Approval Process: Each application will be reviewed individually. Approval will be based on financial need, the event's budget and the number of applicants

docs.title: AI / ML
docs.text:
This category covers the latest advancements and best practices in AI and ML within cloud native environments, exploring innovative applications, tools, and techniques for effective implementation.

It’s designed for professionals who go beyond using provided AI tools and delve into bespoke AI, ML, data science, and AI/ML platform operations, offering insights into managing data models, implementing AI algorithms, deploying ML models in cloud native environments, and optimizing workflows with topics like MLOps, AIOps, AgentOps, GPU utilization with Kubernetes, and more

docs.title: Application Development
docs.text:
This category focuses on the latest practices in cloud native application development and optimizing the developer experience. Designed for software developers and cloud-native architects deploying applications to cloud native environments and the creators of developer-centric tools that keep them focused on software not infrastructure, it offers in-depth insights into architecting, coding, testing, building, and continuous integration (CI) and deployment (CD) of scalable cloud-native applications.

Attendees will explore best practices, architectural patterns, and cutting-edge tools from CNCF projects that streamline the development of complex distributed systems. This track emphasizes strategies for improving developer productivity, simplifying workflows, and enhancing the overall software creation process through innovative tooling and seamless integration of cloud native technologies

docs.title: Connectivity
docs.text:
This category merges Networking + Edge + Telco with Service Mesh topics, offering a deep dive into networking technologies, edge computing, telco applications, and service mesh deployment in cloud native environments.

Ideal for professionals in network engineering, and telecommunications domain, this track covers OSI Layer 4/7 service meshes, load balancing, network security, and automation, providing practical insights into deploying and managing service mesh technologies in production.

docs.title: Data Processing + Storage
docs.text:
This category covers managing data and storage systems in cloud native settings, tackling challenges like scalability and efficient management techniques. Professionals in data processing, storage, database management, and scalability will find valuable insights here.

Attendees will delve into topics such as data streaming, containerized databases, volume provisioning, and optimizing workflows for robust storage solutions in cloud native environments

docs.title: Emerging + Advanced
docs.text:
Content that covers cloud native research & academia, emerging technologies, high performance computing for specialized workloads, and highly advanced cloud native computing concepts. Cloud native research and academic papers are welcome to be presented within this track alongside very early stage technical concepts, proof of concept projects, advancement of research computing, and highly specialized advanced or niche topics.

Attendees interested in the latest advancements in cloud-native technology(the underlying needs associated with sustaining research and academic workloads on cloud native infrastructure, deploying and managing computationally intensive workloads, and highly advanced or in depth technical content relating to cloud native) will likely be drawn to this session(s)

docs.title: Observability
docs.text:
Content that covers methodologies and projects for instrumenting, collecting, processing, storing, querying, curating, and correlating metrics, logging/events, trace spans, and general observational profiling of workloads.

Attendees to these presentations can expect to learn good practices for meaningful alerting, queries, and operational dashboards, tooling and interoperability for observability challenges, and how to manage alerting rules definitions, thresholds and policies

docs.title: Operations + Performance
docs.text:
This category covers operationalizing cloud native projects, optimizing performance, and tackling runtime challenges. Ideal for administrators, SREs, and DevOps professionals, it delves into autoscaling, high availability, performance optimization, operators, and ensuring cluster reliability.

Attendees will leave with enhanced skills in administering, maintaining, and operating cloud native technologies, with a focus on reliability and performance optimization

docs.title: Platform Engineering
docs.text:
This category covers essential topics such as building and customizing cloud native platforms, automating infrastructure operations, and improving self-service workflows for developers. It caters to platform engineers, DevOps professionals, infrastructure architects, and developers interested in these areas.

Attendees will gain insights into integrating cloud native projects, extending platform functionalities, and accelerating software delivery velocity through effective toolchain and workflow enhancements

docs.title: Security
docs.text:
Content that covers the security specific aspects of cloud native from detections to threat modeling, security education, identity and credential management, multi-tenancy, confidential computing, vulnerability management in cloud native, and other topics.

Attendees to these presentations can expect to learn tactics and techniques in defending and designing cloud native architecture secure from attacks at all portions of the architecture and SDLC, managing credentials and identities, zero trust concepts and tooling, supply chain considerations, and learn from security audits of projects or incident post-mortems

docs.title: Others
docs.text: If you believe your session doesn't fall into any of those categories or if you're not sure, set your category as Others

docs.title: Beginner
docs.text: Beginner sessions are designed for those with minimal to no prior knowledge of the topic. These talks focus on the fundamentals and basic concepts, with minimal use of jargon. Presenters avoid assuming any technical background and instead offer high-level overviews that introduce key technologies, tools or workflows in simple terms. These sessions aim to build awareness and provide foundational understanding, often using illustrative examples or analogies

docs.title: Intermediate
docs.text: Intermediate sessions assume that attendees have some experience with the topic at hand. These talks delve deeper into practical applications, workflows and tools, offering real-world examples and often demonstrating how to implement certain technologies. While some jargon is used, it's typically explained as the presentation progresses. The goal here is to help attendees build their skills and gain a more nuanced understanding of the subject

docs.title: Advanced
docs.text: Advanced sessions cater to highly experienced professionals with a deep understanding of the subject matter. These talks explore complex systems, architectural patterns and optimizations, often focusing on specialized topics such as performance tuning, system design or advanced security techniques. Expect a significant amount of technical jargon and detailed code walkthroughs, as these sessions are designed to deepen knowledge for those already working in the field

docs.title: Session Type
docs.text:
• Presentation: 30 minutes, 1-2 speaker(s) presenting on a topic
  • Panel Discussion: 30 minutes of discussion amongst 3 to 5 speakers (with a moderator appointed by KCD Kuala Lumpur)
  • Lightning Talk: A brief 5-minute presentation, maximum of 1 speaker
  • Workshop: 60-minute, in-depth, hands-on presentation with 1-3 speakers

docs.title: Submission Guideline
docs.text: To help us curate a diverse and high-quality program for KCD Kuala Lumpur, please keep the following in mind when submitting your proposal

docs.title: Code of Conduct
docs.text: All speakers are required to adhere to CNCF's Code of Conduct

docs.title: Avoid AI slop
docs.text: Avoid submitting low-effort, AI-generated proposals. While we don't ban the use of AI, especially since it can be a helpful tool for non-native English speakers, we strongly discourage submissions that appear to be low-quality or clearly AI-generated slop

docs.title: Maximum of 3 submissions per speaker
docs.text: You may propose up to three different sessions. This allows flexibility while ensuring fairness in the review process

docs.title: Choose the appropriate session type and category
docs.text: Please select the format that best fits your content (refer to Session Type page). Clear session types make it easier for our committee to evaluate your proposal. You should also select the correct content category as listed in Session Category

docs.title: Panel sessions require diversity
docs.text: For panel discussions, we prioritize diverse representation across backgrounds, companies, experience levels, and gender to ensure a richer, more balanced conversation

docs.title: Travel support depends on budget
docs.text: Accommodation and/or flight reimbursement for speakers from Sabah, Sarawak and overseas might be available, subject to our event budget. We will update the details later on.

docs.title: Avoid sales pitch
docs.text: Avoid sales or marketing pitches and discussing unlicensed or potentially closed-source technologies when preparing your proposal; these talks are almost always rejected due to the fact that they take away from the integrity of our event. Make sure your content is open source and vendor neutral

docs.title: Attach slides (optional)
docs.text: Attach slides with your submission as that could help us better understand your session. This is optional, but we highly encourage you to upload the slides

docs.title: Submit Your Session
docs.text:
We use sessionize platform for call for speakers, also known as CFS or CFP. Submit your sessions here by 28th Feb 2026 11:59pm.

While it is not our intention to provide you with strict instructions on how to prepare your submission, we hope you will take a moment to review the following guidelines that we have put together to help you prepare the best submission possible. To get started, here are three things that you should consider before submitting:

  1. What are you hoping to get from your presentation?
  2. What do you expect the audience to gain from your presentation?
  3. How will your presentation help better the ecosystem?

There are plenty of ways to give a presentation about projects and technologies without focusing on company-specific / vendor-specific features. Remember the things to consider that we mentioned above when submitting your session and think of ways to make it interesting for attendees while still letting you share your experiences, educate the community about an issue, or generate interest on a topic.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Submission: Submit a proposal for the session by the deadline. You can always edit the submission till the deadline.
  2. Review process: KCD Kuala Lumpur CFP committee will review all submissions and select speakers based on criteria such as the quality of the topic, relevance and alignment with the event's goals
  3. Confirmation and preparation: Once selected, the speaker is notified and may begin (or continue) preparing their session according to the guidelines
  4. Complimentary event pass: One complimentary pass for the event will be provided for each accepted speaker

docs.title: Guideline to submit
docs.text: Refer to Submission Guideline, Session Type, Session Category and Session Difficulty Level

docs.title: How to Give a Great Talk
docs.text: We want to make sure submitters receive resources to help put together a great submission and if accepted, give the best presentation possible. To help with this, we recommend viewing seasoned speaker Dawn Foster’s in-depth talk on Getting Over Your Imposter Syndrome to Become a Conference Speaker – Dawn Foster, VMware

docs.title: Our Inspiration for This Guideline
docs.text: We would like to thank CNCF and the KubeCon + CloudNativeCon CFP committee for sharing the documentation on how to submit a session. Our guideline is heavily inspired from the forementioned KubeCon + CloudNativeCon documentation
